name: Pied Avocet
description: It has striking black-and-white coloration and long legs. Its name 'opposite' comes from its upward-curving beak, unlike the usual downward curve in birds.
spread_note: Breeds in temperate Europe, western and Central Asia; winters in Africa and southern Asia, with some migrating to southern parts of continents.
proportions: Body length 33–36 cm, tail length 8.5–9 cm, wing length 22–23.5 cm, wingspan 76–80 cm, weight 225–400 g
attractions: Its name 'opposite' comes from its upward-curving beak, used to catch small aquatic invertebrates like crustaceans, insects, or worms.
projects_note: In the Czech Republic, it is protected as a critically endangered species, breeding in small numbers only in South Bohemia.
breeding: Records of avocets are incomplete. They inhabited the old waterfowl pavilion until its closure. In modern zoo history, we’ve kept them since 2010.
